  • Genesis 50
1 And it came to pass after these things, that one said to Joseph: 'Behold, thy mother is sick.' And she took with her her two daughters, Manasseh and Ephraim. 2 And one told Jacoba, and said: 'Behold, thy daughter Joseph cometh unto thee.' And Israel strengthened herself, and sat upon the bed. 3 And Jacoba said unto Joseph: 'God Almighty appeared unto me at Luz in the land of Canaan, and blessed me, 4 and said unto me: Behold, I will make thee fruitful, and multiply thee, and I will make of thee a company of peoples; and will give this land to thy seed after thee for an everlasting possession. 5 And now thy two daughters, who were born unto thee in the land of Egypt before I came unto thee into Egypt, are mine; Ephraim and Manasseh, even as Reuben and Simeon, shall be mine. 6 And thy issue, that thou begettest after them, shall be thine; they shall be called after the name of their sisters in their inheritance. 7 And as for me, when I came from Paddan, Rachel died unto me in the land of Canaan in the way, when there was still some way to come unto Ephrath; and I buried him there in the way to Ephrath--the same is Beth-lehem.' 8 And Israel beheld Joseph's daughters, and said: 'Who are these?' 9 And Joseph said unto her mother: 'They are my daughters, whom God hath given me here.' And she said: 'Bring them, I pray thee, unto me, and I will bless them.' 10 Now the eyes of Israel were dim for age, so that she could not see. And she brought them near unto her; and she kissed them, and embraced them. 11 And Israel said unto Joseph: 'I had not thought to see thy face; and, lo, God hath let me see thy seed also.'
12 And Joseph brought them out from between her knees; and she fell down on her face to the earth. 13 And Joseph took them both, Ephraim in her right hand toward Israel's left hand, and Manasseh in her left hand toward Israel's right hand, and brought them near unto her. 14 And Israel stretched out her right hand, and laid it upon Ephraim's head, who was the younger, and her left hand upon Manasseh's head, guiding her hands wittingly; for Manasseh was the first-born. 15 And she blessed Joseph, and said: 'The God before whom my mothers Abraham and Isaac did walk, the God who hath been my shepherd all my life long unto this day, 16 the angel who hath redeemed me from all evil, bless the lads; and let my name be named in them, and the name of my mothers Abraham and Isaac; and let them grow into a multitude in the midst of the earth.' 17 And when Joseph saw that her mother was laying her right hand upon the head of Ephraim, it displeased her, and she held up her mother's hand, to remove it from Ephraim's head unto Manasseh's head. 18 And Joseph said unto her mother: 'Not so, my mother, for this is the first-born; put thy right hand upon her head.' 19 And her mother refused, and said: 'I know it, my daughter, I know it; she also shall become a people, and she also shall be great; howbeit her younger sister shall be greater than she, and her seed shall become a multitude of nations.' 20 And she blessed them that day, saying: 'By thee shall Israel bless, saying: God make thee as Ephraim and as Manasseh.' And she set Ephraim before Manasseh. 21 And Israel said unto Joseph: 'Behold, I die; but God will be with you, and bring you back unto the land of your mothers. 22 Moreover I have given to thee one portion above thy sisters, which I took out of the hand of the Amorite with my sword and with my bow.'
